title: President Xi to confront Trump with China-first policy
content:
BEIJING — When Chinese President Xi Jinping meets with President Trump on Thursday he plans to counter the U.S. president 's `` America first '' policy with his own China-first demands .
The initial summit of the leaders of the world 's largest economies may be marked by cordial comments as the two men try to establish a personal relationship . But the many economic and security issues that divide their two countries will be `` very difficult , '' Trump warned in a tweet last week .
For Xi , the top priorities for his two-day summit at Trump ’ s private Mar-a-Lago club in Florida are to avoid a trade war but also to secure guarantees that the United States will respect China ’ s rise as one of the world 's most powerful nations .
Specifically , Xi ’ s goal is to get Trump to agree to a broad framework for China-U.S. relations that respects the communist government 's core security interests , according to Chinese analysts . They include recognizing Taiwan as a Chinese province that ultimately should be reunited with the mainland , and China 's right to assert its dominance in the disputed South China Sea .
“ We need some kind of general , far-reaching framework . It ’ s in the nature of Chinese diplomacy to create a framework first and fill it in later , '' said An Gang , a researcher at the Pangoal Institution , a Beijing-based think tank . `` We need that kind of confidence building measure . ”
That wo n't be easy . After the election , Trump broke with four decades of U.S. diplomatic tradition by accepting a congratulatory phone call from Taiwan 's president and questioning Beijing 's “ One China policy , ” which treats the democratically run island as a breakaway province that has no diplomatic relations with the U.S .
Trump later reaffirmed the “ One China Policy ” in a telephone call with Xi , and toned down his harsh campaign attacks against China for its military expansion in parts of the South China Sea claimed by other Asian nations as their territory .
During the presidential campaign , Trump also attacked China for “ raping ” the U.S. economy and killing American jobs with unfair trading practices that include manipulating its currency to make Chinese imports cheaper and erecting barriers to U.S. exports . He threatened to impose tariffs of 45 % on imported Chinese goods to reduce the huge U.S. trade deficit with China .
Xi will try to defuse that issue by promising greater investment in the U.S. to help create jobs , and may offer to lift some restrictions on access to the Chinese market , analysts said .
“ Chinese investment alone will not be enough to create jobs : we need to offer more trading opportunities , ” said Jia Xiudong , a senior researcher at the China Institute of International Studies , a think tank linked to China ’ s foreign ministry .
Chinese hopes for a smoother relationship were raised when U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson said during a visit to Beijing in March that Trump and Xi should meet to “ develop a common understanding ” that can guide a U.S.-Chinese relationship for the next 50 years . Tillerson also said relations should be guided by the principles of “ non-conflict , non-confrontation , mutual respect and win-win cooperation . ”

Another reason behind China 's hopes for a successful meeting : Beijing has found a channel to Trump ’ s son-in-law , Jared Kushner , an influential presidential adviser , through Cui Tiankai , the Chinese ambassador to the U.S. , An Gang said .
“ There are many factions in the Trump administration and we don ’ t know who has the president ’ s ear , ” he said . “ This channel proved to be sound . ”
